caption: A very beautiful museum and library in Paris. I would say THE BEST. They have manuscripts from several regions over the world. I saw rigveda and Mahabharata for the first time in my Life in this museum. They also display a lot of French culture. It also has a really beautiful library. A must visit when in Paris.

The Museum of the BibliothÃ¨que de France (Library of France) covers humanity and culture. So precious objects that tell the story of humanity's evolution are here. The reading room is equally as impressive: arts and culture are covered as well as a great section for kids.
Go it is free and not too crowded If you like medals ,the artwork of it and some Olympic memorabilia pertaining to Olympians from France this is a great spot to educate about the history
I always wanted to go there... and that didnt disappoint! Building is amazing, the rooms are stunning, not to mention the different collections they have. Staff was extremely nice too.
Great Museum, beautiful architecture and pieces. The 2 main rooms of the library itself are free to visit, but prepare yourself for a long wait.
Outstanding collection of antiquities and manuscripts in an amazing building. Quiet and uncrowded experience. Very chic neighborhood of Palais Royal. A must see in Paris

A phenomenal little museum in a beautiful library! I'm not usually an antiquities person but their collection is magnificent. The interactive displays were so well done that it actually made me interested in red-figure pottery! The temporary exhibit on revolutions in Paris was a master class in museum design and very informative as an American whose knowledge of French history begins and ends in the 1790s. In addition to its collections, the library is full of wonderful architecture from the 17th through 21st centuries; I stared at the mythology frescoes on the ceiling of the Mazarin Gallery for a good 20 minutes.  Not a "must-see" like the Louvre or MusÃ©e d'Orsay, but if you're a museum nerd like me, you'll have a great time. Plus it's free if you're under 26!

I've been there by coincidence. If you're under 26 and live in Europe you can enter for free apparently. As for the exhibitions they're good and worth taking a look at. They have a huge library that looks so impressive.
Really worth a visit. Especially a guided visit with Maelys Robin. We loved her energy and passion!
Nice to visit, though signage not in English.
Beautiful refurnished main reading room. However, unfortunately the other room which was open to visits in the past, was closed. The stairs are also stunning.
Interesting building and lots of historical artefacts

As far as i am concerned pass on the museum unless you have a special interest on old coins and vases. Aim towards the oval room which is free and incredibly beautiful. Grab a book and stay there the rest of the day. IMO.
The museum is good, and the oval room is quite impressive. I do not recommend trying to get to the museum if you're paying full price.
Nice museum with a Gutenberg Bible, Grand Cameo de France and other interesting books and small objects. The reading rooms are really beautiful too
Show stopping installation. Building and grounds are beautiful. Staff very friendly
Very historic experience
Simply beautiful

Exceptionnal place .Fantastic oval library

A very nice museum. The renovation has beautified the spaces and the collections. There are only masterpieces. The reception and surveillance teams are friendly (a special mention for the lady at the ticket office who was adorable). I highly recommend!

Pleasant surprise this place. A little gem in Paris. They have a large collection of works and art. The library area is free and the museum costs $10 euros. There are not so many people so you can enjoy them pleasantly. I hope you can meet him.

I had to wait in line to get in even though it was raining. I went there to read the scriptures because I was a doctoral student, but unfortunately they said that only art students could read the manuscript and most of them operated on a paid basis. The places you can enter for free are crowded with tourists, so you can't actually get a seat.

The site of the National Library of France (BNF) called Richelieu after its founder is the oldest place in the national library network. It contains a small museum (8 rooms) but containing extraordinary works ranging from antiquity to the 21st century. You can also visit the reading room called Labrouste, named after the architect who created one of the first metal constructions in France.
A magical experience. Small but rich museum, and above all lively, full of busy researchers on the relics of the past. If this museum is so beautiful, it is also because we know it is loved.

It is a magical place where history, discovery and literature combine. The Oval Room is incredible, itâ€™s every literature loverâ€™s dream. The museum is also very interesting, with copies of emblematic works.

Discovery of the BNF museum during the exhibitions dedicated to Damien Deroubaix and BarthÃ©lÃ©my Toguo. In addition to interesting temporary exhibitions, the museum presents superb antique objects including the Berthouville treasure.
Very nice. The rooms are magnificent, particularly the Oval room with free access. Leafing through the Gutemberg Bible was particularly pleasantâ€¦

This is a museum located in the National Library of France that opened in 2023. There are valuable exhibits from a wide range of eras, including not only France, but also Egypt and ancient Rome, which is very interesting. The furniture is very nice, and you can enjoy the atmosphere of visiting a small castle. A full-length portrait of Louis XIV was also on display. Valuable items were on display, including paintings depicting the Bastille fortress, where the French Revolution began, and handwritten musical scores by Mozart and Beethoven. It's located right between the Opera Garnier and the Louvre Museum, so it's easy to access, and it's a good size, so we recommend it.

Little known but very interesting museum. The building has been restored from top to bottom and has become accessible to everyone. Elevators, reading room toilets. The entrance fee to the Museum is 10â‚¬
Very impressive historic building!  Not that busy despite my visit on a Saturday afternoon which is nice.
Superb establishment!!! It's simply magnificent!! We visited it during heritage days.

More than the museum, the trip is especially true for the entire site. The collections are beautiful and interesting but above all well presented. A beautiful walk and we discover that the oval reading room is freely accessible.

Visit yesterday March 5, in a small group with a guide. An extraordinary collection of precious objects acquired by kings or bequeathed by rich collectors, an instructive presentation of writings, manuscripts, printing techniques, cultural exchanges between peoples. Exciting.
